When they take down the rice (of last year; that is in the rumah adat), they sing a song Tena Lau Kese, "A boat that is sailing".
Kong gitong

Some songs are in a different language (see next question's notes). Some songs are in an old version of Hewa that most people don't understand. But there are also songs in Hewa: Bau Bala is a Hewa song in Hewa.

Songs with words from Boru (if Boru is a different language). An example is recorded of a song in Boru Kedang. This song is sung when treading the rice after harvest.The song Tena Lau Kese (10.4) is in the Mohang language.
4 men and 6 women
sakalele: male's dance, lusi lerang: women's dance
Kebek bakur: after harvesting, pleba watar: after harvesting corn

Some arrived in boats, some came from Boru, Lamaholot or Sika, and some came out of the ground. The Hewa ancestors are 2 kings: one married with a Maumere woman (in Muhang) and one went to Larantuka, travelling across the mountains, but never quite got there and stayed in Hewa. Muhang was used as a language before, but now it's gone from Hewa.
the rumah adat
ancestors who came out of the ground
catholic pastor
arak, tuak, sirih pinang
Traditional midwife = molan. Baby must stay inside the house for 5 days. This period is referred to as Lohor dedi.

ri': after harvest of the rice in the garden, kebek bakur: after harvest of the rice in the rumah adat; pleba watar: at the harvest of the corn

east: wali, west: ripa; south: lau, north: reta

Hewa has 27 clans; including: Liwu, Boru, Rotan, Soge, Ipir, Widin, Uran, Tapun, Kei, Pu'e, Maau, Liwu Maran, Soge Getei, Liwu Getei, Liwi Kur, Lewuk.

Widin are autochtonous, the original kings, they are the most important. Followed by the Soge. The remaining 24 clans are in the middle. The Tapun are the lowest in rank. They are the newcomers, the smallest group, and considered not much fun to talk to.
The Widin clan.
everything goes to (eldest) son
It may happen but only if the son feels pity for his sister(s).
They buy from the owner.
20-30 men (most around 24); 16-28 women (most around 18)
1. Certain clans do not marry each other: Widin-Soge is forbidden, Liwu-Plu'e is forbidden, Kei-Ipir is forbidden. 2. Marriage between cousins is always forbidden.
sirih pinang, tembako kasar, beras, ayam bakar, arak 1 bottle, 1 male goat
Wife moves to husband's group only if the bridewealth is paid, otherwise the husband moves into the wife's group until it is paid.
Ivory; if that is not available, then money
a ring, clothes for the wedding
Until the 1970's the people of Hewa lived in 8 different places. Now there are still 4 groups living elsewhere outside the village.
they can be in the mountains but not necessarily on hilltops
They can be on the shore but this is not necessary.
kantor desa, church
There was a guerilla war against the Japanese. The Dua Toru made the guns. There have also been wars with the Lewo Ingo about land rights. In these fights, Koa Boru from Hewa was the hero.

Original Hewa are the Ketan from the coast. There are differences in appearances and in the ceremonies of the coast and those inland. On the coast, they keep all the ceremonies, whereas not all of them are kept inland. On the coast, special groups have special tasks, e.g.Boru Dera are the cutters of meat, the Lotar and Ona are the people who serve the food.
the Widin clan derives from the traditional ancestor king.
Trade relations with Larantuka, Sika, Boru; barter exchange of rice and corn
